entry.title: The New Explore Migration Objects App, The Game Changer in Planning Your Data Migration
entry.content:
A Short Trip to History

Since people have been performing data migrations into different systems, they have wanted to know the dependencies between the various data they need to migrate. They usually create project plans, PowerPoint presentations, or use tools like Visio to make these dependencies visible. As the saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words. Since SAP began delivering preconfigured data migration objects, initially as a Rapid Deployment Solution for SAP ECC, later for SAP S/4HANA, and then as migration objects for the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit, customers have repeatedly asked for an overview diagram of the dependencies of these objects.

Initially, when the number of migration objects was manageable, there was an attempt to create an overview diagram in Visio. The interim result, shown in Figure 1, reflects only a portion of the objects present at that time. Each additional object made the diagram increasingly confusing.

Paper Draft

Figure 1, Paper Draft

The data initially resembled a sewing machine pattern or the London Tube Map, making it unusable.

Since the data was already in the system, the dependencies of a migration object were listed in the SAP Help Portal documentation. Customers could view them there. Later, this information was also included in the overview list of "Available Migration Objects."

There have always been efforts to provide customers with an interactive map. Initially, we considered displaying it on a web page using Python's network graph tool. However, this approach failed due to technical, hosting, and maintenance problems.

The Tile of Happiness

After a long wait filled with much effort, numerous usability tests with internal and external consultants, and feedback from customers, we are proud to present the first version of the Explore Migration Objects app. Internally, we refer to it as the EMO app.

The idea to use the SAP Fiori Network Graph and offer it in an easy-to-use app was a decisive turning moment. We began with an initial draft version and conducted several usability tests to determine users' needs and the desired design. Based on the test results, we finalized the app and delivered it through CFD and a feature toggle in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, the app is available without a feature toggle.

Spoiler: In the near future, users may choose between an "empty" tile and a tile that shows the number of available migration objects delivered by SAP within the current release.

 

 

 




Figure 2, The Tiles

How does the app support data migration?

The app assists you with planning your data migrations. It provides a graphical overview of data migration objects and their mandatory or optional predecessor objects. This offers a complete view of the entire data migration scope or individual subareas. You can quickly identify necessary dependent predecessor migration objects. Additionally, you can navigate from each migration object to its documentation on the SAP Help Portal. This makes it easier and faster to familiarize yourself with the details of a migration object.

It helps you plan your data migration scope and the sequence to extract and load your data. You can also determine data migration objects by entering a scope item (business process) to see which migration objects are assigned to it. This helps you check if your planned scope covers all data migration objects or identify which objects might be relevant.

The app is continually enhanced with new functionality in future releases. However, as data migrations in SAP S/4HANA and Private Cloud are not assigned to scope items, this functionality is not supported in those product versions.

For which product and release is the version available, and how do you activate it?

The Explore Migration Objects app (F8638) is available with SAP S/4HANA versions 2508.3 and 2508.4. To activate it, enable the feature Enable new app for Explore Migration objects (CFND_DMCC_NEW_APP_EXPLORE_01).

For more details on activating apps through features, please refer to the What's New Document on the SAP Help Portal

With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, the app is generally available in the data migration group without needing activation. For SAP S/4HANA and Private Cloud, the app is available with SAP S/4HANA 2025FPS1. However, for SAP S/4HANA 2023 or earlier releases, the app is not available. These products are already in the support package phase, and new features and apps may only be delivered during the feature pack phase.

What authorization do I need?

If you already have authorization for the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit, you can use this app too.

Which approaches are supported?

The first version of the app currently supports only the migration objects built for the Staging Tables approach. Support for the Direct Transfer approach (DT) is planned for later versions as the framework for that approach is enhanced with additional functionality.

Where can I find the app?

The app is assigned to the Data Migration page. Especially during the controlled feature delivery phase in version 2508.4, you may need to search for the app by its name and assign it to your page manually.

Data Migration GroupFigure 3, Data Migration Group

How do I use the app?

Selecting the data

The app is structured like most SAP Fiori apps: it includes a selection area and a result area. The selection area displays three different selection fields:

  1. A "Search" field where you can enter a freely defined search string.
  2. A "Migration Object" field where you can enter or select one or more migration objects.
  3. A "Scope Item" field where you can select one or more scope items.

Selection area

Figure 4, Selection area

The results area shows the results of your selection based on the selection field where you entered your search term. It is divided into one area by two tab bars to display migration objects and scope items in a table. When you enter a search string into the search field, the system returns all migration objects and scope items that contain that search string. 

Some Example

For example, if you enter "Asset" into the search field, it returns all migration objects containing that search string. When you enter or select a value in the “Migration Object” field, a proposal list first appears. You can then select values from this list.

Result area, Migration Objects Tab
Figure 5, Result area, Migration Objects Tab

You can also use the value help to search and select one or multiple objects.

Migration Objects Field, Value Help

Figure 6,  Migration Objects Field, Value Help

If you select the "Go" button or press the Enter key, the system displays the result. This result differs from what you obtain through the search field. Searching with the "Migration Object" field provides relevant migration objects…

Result area, Migration Objects Tab

 Figure 7, Result area, Migration Objects Tab

…and the scope items to which these objects are assigned.

Result area, Scope Items Tab

Figure 8, Result area, Scope Items Tab

When you search using the "Scope Item" field, the "Migration Objects" tab lists all migration objects assigned to these scope items. You can find the related scope items on the "Scope Items" tab.

You can combine the "Search" field with either the “Migration Object” field or the “Scope Item” field. However, do not use the “Migration Object” field and the “Scope Item” field together. The search results vary based on which of the three search fields you complete. 

Now, let's focus on the most important aspect: what you can actually do with it in the app.

The graphical overview for migration objects

Search for the Migration Object "Material BOM", and select it from the result list. The selection view changes to display the “Migration Object” view. The migration object "Material BOM" and its alias (BOM_3) appear in the title section. The migration object and its dependent predecessor objects are shown as nodes within a network diagram. Each object appears as a blue node within a group that indicates the migration domain to which the migration object belongs. "Material BOM" is assigned to a domain called "Basic Data." The domain name is derived from the application component description to which the object belongs. You can see the alias and the technical name of the component within the blue node. The alias is a technical construct that is part of the technical name of a data migration object. Knowing the alias name of a migration object can be very useful.

Network GraphFigure 9, Network Graph

Connectors illustrate the relationships between migration objects. Upon closer inspection, you'll notice different types of connectors linking the objects. Dashed gray lines represent connections to optional predecessor migration objects. Solid orange lines indicate mandatory predecessor objects, such as "Product" in the example shown.

Network Graph Connectors

Figure 10, Network Graph Connectors

Functions

The toolbar displays various fields and functions. It includes a search field where users can enter a string to find an object in larger network diagrams and navigate to that object.

Initially, the direction of the objects runs from left to right. This means the root object is on the left side, and all others are arranged to the right. Use the “Transpose” button to change the direction from left-right to top-bottom. This can sometimes make it easier to get an overview of larger diagrams or take a better screenshot.

Next to the “Transpose” button is the “Legend” button, which displays the legend. Next to it, you can find the zoom buttons. You can either zoom in or zoom out. Between the two buttons, the zoom factor is displayed as a percentage. Next to the zoom area is the "Zoom to Fit" button. It zooms the diagram so that all nodes are displayed on the screen.

ToolbarFigure 11, Toolbar

The "Enter to Full Screen" button displays the diagram in a separate window. In some browsers with built-in screenshot functionality, such as Microsoft Edge or Firefox, it's sometimes useful to switch to full screen before taking a screenshot.

Directly to the right of the toolbar, you'll find the graph overview. Some users may already be familiar with this feature from other applications or the ABAP Dictionary transaction SE11. In SE11, you could display a graphical overview of tables and their dependencies, where it was called the navigation area. The graph overview helps prevent losing track in very large network diagrams. It always shows the complete network diagram in a small window. A small blue window within the graph overview indicates the current section of the diagram displayed on the screen. You can move the blue window to the section you want to display.

Graph OverviewFigure 12, Graph Overview

Interactions on a node

Clicking on a node opens a menu. This menu offers options to expand or collapse the predecessor structure of the migration objects or to display the links popover.

Interactions on a node

Figure 13, Interactions on a node

In the links popover, accessible through the "Node Links" icon   , you find the direct link to the documentation of the migration object on SAP Help Portal. Future versions may also include links to available sample data for the migration object. These samples are already provided on the SAP Help Portal.

Documentation LinksFigure 14, Documentation Links

Similar to a node, you can also collapse   or expand  a group. When collapsed, the group displays only its name.

Collapse Group
Figure 15, Collapse Group

You can use the Group Details icon   to view all migration objects assigned to a collapsed group. If the main object is in a collapsed group, a home icon appears in front of its name.

Group Details IconFigure 16, Group Details Icon

Clicking on a connector or the area surrounding it calls up the connector's detail popover.

Connector's detail popoverFigure 17, Connector's detail popover

You can expand each migration object that has a predecessor object to display these predecessor objects. Simply click the "Expand Migration Objects" icon  .

Figure 18, Expand Migration Objects

The graphical overview for scope items

In this example, we use "Asset" as the search term for the scope items, then select “1IH” – "Intercompany Asset Transfer Within Same Country". The functionality of the "Scope Items" view matches that of the view for migration objects. The scope item node appears as a circular shape. Each migration object connects to the scope item in the first release of the app with a solid orange line. In future versions, this solid line changes to a dashed gray line to clarify that such objects aren't mandatory for a scope item.

Network graph Scope ItemFigure 19, Network graph Scope Item

More to Come: A Short Outlook on Ideas

Several additional features are planned or under discussion. One example is an option to display either all available objects delivered by SAP with a release or only the activated migration objects. The latter option shows the same objects that customers see when selecting an object within the migration cockpit. Migration objects assigned to a non-standard scope item that is not activated will not be shown. The same applies to migration objects available only if a business function, such as retail-related objects, is activated.

There are also discussions about displaying the migration object type, indicating whether it is a master data or transaction data object. Additionally, there are plans to show whether a migration object supports key user extensibility.

Once the Direct Transfer approach framework expands to support the EMO app, these migration objects and their dependencies are expected to be available with the app.

Since almost all usability testers saw no need for a download or print function, such a function is not currently planned. Instead, you can use the integrated screenshot functionality provided in several web browsers, such as Firefox and Edge on Microsoft Windows and Apple macOS.

Outlook on SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud

The EMO app is available with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS1. It offers almost the same functionality as the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3/2602 app. However, the scope item functionality isn't available for SAP S/4HANA because migration objects within SAP S/4HANA aren't assigned to scope items. Functions provided within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition CFD or main releases are likely added to SAP S/4HANA FPS2 and FPS3.

Feel free to share your opinions about the app in the comments section of this blog. You can also suggest new functions and features you might be missing.

P.S. My personal kudo goes to @vishnuvardhantanguturu, Miller Li, Zak Zhang, and @Martina_H, my colleagues in development and product management that worked hard in the last 9 months to deliver the baby in time. Special Thanks also to Joshua Sturm, for checking the blog text before delivery.

entry.title: Manufacturing Dates Report for Unitized Materials in SAP PEO
entry.content:
[Blog Type: Hands-on Expertise]

 

Summary

This blog post describes an approach to how to implement in SAP S/4HANA a progress report containing the planned and actual production dates at every assembly step (section-material, position-operation) for every model-unit of a project. This report is crucial for planners and rest of the organization, giving visibility about the dates/status of the different complex products while moving on the shop floor.

The target audience for this blog post will be consulting people, project team members, key users, and subject matter experts who are interested on production engineering and operations within SAP S/4HANA.

 

Introduction

Complex product structures in SAP S/4HANA are managed with a combination of Project System (PS) and Production Engineering and Operations (PEO). Complex assembly industries use model-unit effectivity to control the configuration of an assembly product. PEO uses classical parameter effectivity in Engineering Change Management (ECM) to implement model-unit effectivity, what is known as product unitization.

Product unitization is a mechanism of managing multiple configurations of an assembly and its production process plan (routing) in a way that all the possible units can be modeled using the same super bill of material and super routing. When a particular unit is to be produced, the super bill of material and related super routing are filtered to retrieve only the information relevant for that unit and assigned to the production order.

You can use materials of different types to model the assemblies used in complex assembly manufacturing:

  • An End Item (EI) represents the final product, i.e. a complete aircraft, which is often not represented by a single BOM, but by a set of BOMs, i.e. major assemblies.
  • A Major Assembly (MA) is unitized, i.e. configurable and represents a large section of the product such as a wing or center fuselage section.
  • An Installation Kit (IK) is an organizational breakdown of the major assembly. An IK represents the work content, which can be handled, for example, in one shift.

Image 1. Complex product structure in SAP S/4HANA.

The image below depicts an example of a manufacturing layout for assembling a complex product.

Image 2. Example of manufacturing layout for assembling complex products.

Imaging a complex product which consists of 4 parts lists, and consequently 4 routings. This means that routing is created for each line segment/section of the production process. This is a mechanism to ensure the flexibility of the planning. Whether having an independent order or just an operation/position of the overall order will depend on when to establish sequence changes between positions.

Typically, the complex product goes through several positions on the line until its complete. For example, the second line section on the image has a total of 6 positions. The installation processes which take place on every position are referred as an installation kit. The underlying routing serves only to coordinate installation activities and thus do not represent executable routings. This means the line work centers are only for orchestration, as the actual work is always done on the installation work centers.

For example, on section 2 of line 1 the product can stay 3 days on one position until the move to the next position, while on same section of line 2 the product stays 4 days on one position. This means line 1 is faster than line 2, for example, because on line 1 the fastest people work. The time that passes until all products are moved by one position is called the takt time. Takt time duration is defined in the routing. The bottleneck work centers are crucial for the scheduling of each position and detailed scheduling is based on these resources.

Only by having this manufacturing layout you can define and plan that each component is available at the right time, that you have the right workers at the right time, and that you have the right resources at the right time.

To get an overview of the manufacturing dates/status of the different complex products at the different stages, a progress report with the planned and actual production dates for every model-unit is used. This report is critical for having manufacturing visibility for planners and rest of the organization. Below you can find an example of this report on Microsoft Excel.

Image 3. Example of manufacturing dates report on Microsoft Excel.

This blog post describes an implementation approach to this manufacturing dates report in SAP S/4HANA.

 

Requirements of the Manufacturing Dates Report

For a correct orchestration of the whole assembly process for unitized products, planners need to have an overview of the planned and actual dates of the key planning elements of an assembled product with engineering-to-order (ETO) processes. Customer requested to have a report in a similar format to Microsoft Excel, containing all these manufacturing dates for every model and unit belonging to a specific project.

The main requirements of this manufacturing dates report were the following:

  • The report will be related to the upper levels of the complex product structure, where the planning elements are related to operative WBS elements, so no elements managed under the grouping WBS element.
  • The report will only take care of the planning elements under a single configuration level, since the relationship between the different configuration levels elements does not exist. The identification of the configuration level of a model will be done by the assignation of a specific model type (for example, aircraft final assembly, left wing, center fuselage, wheelset).
  • Initially only the internally produced materials will be considered as supply elements for the report. Therefore, only planned orders and production orders will be considered.
  • The report will assume that every model and unit of the configuration level is manufactured/assembled in one single plant.
  • To identify the planning elements relevant for every model-unit, the system will use the effectivity parameters (model and unit) of every planning element.

Image 4. Example of assignation of model type (configuration level) to models.

You must consider that model-unit effectivity can only be used if the material and all its parents are subject to make-to-project planning, that it, the planning elements are related to operative WBS elements.

As customer was using an external project management software tool to manage project planning, the main assumptions about this tool were the following:

  • The tool will send the planned finish date/time for every model-unit of every complex product on the different configuration levels, and this will be done in the network activity material reservations on SAP S/4HANA.
  • The tool will define the planned assembly line for every model-unit, and this will be done in the network activity work center on SAP S/4HANA.

Customer requirement was to have this finish date (“target date”) from the external tool also displayed on the manufacturing dates report, to be able to compare dates from external tool with dates proposed by MRP Live on SAP S/4HANA, and thus verifying alignment or misalignment.

The planned finish date/time coming from the external project tool was also the basis for the scheduling of the orders, together with the takt time. The takt time of the line represents the duration of the operation of the order (whatever process done), and it is defined in the routing. The planned assembly line coming from the external project tool was used to align all the work centers of the pegging tree order operation.

 

Design of the Manufacturing Dates Report

The expected layout of the customer for the manufacturing dates report in SAP S/4HANA was the following:

Image 5. Design of the expected layout for the manufacturing dates report.

The true challenge of this report was to make the report dynamic and able to indicate the relevant planning elements required for every different project, regardless of the configuration level, of the product, of the assembly process and/or the different assembly operations.

This was achieved by creating a configuration tool with the following three levels of configuration, allowing a dynamic column layout visualization:

  1. Level 1 = Layouts level. This level contains the different layouts and the corresponding layout definition and assignation to model type.
  2. Level 2 = Columns level. This level contains the numbered columns where the planning element needs to be placed in the report, and the type of date to be placed for the referenced element. For every column, a column description will be maintained as the alias of the specific assembly process taking place. There are two date types:
    1. Material date: date comes from header dates of planning element.
    2. Operation date: date comes from operation dates of planning element. The operation number in this case is filled on column Operation.
  3. Level 3 = Columns criteria level. This level contains the material/s for which the planning elements and their dates need to be selected for every column.

Image 6. Design of the layout configuration for the manufacturing dates report.

For every model-unit, the report will display three different lines showing different types of dates:

  • Target Dates
  • Plan Dates
  • Real Dates

For every date to be shown, the report will display two different columns, one with the Start Date and the other with the Finish Date of the corresponding planning element.

Target Dates will be the dates defined by Planning Department and coming from the external project management software tool, and they will be defined in the Network Activity Material Reservations (table RESB) in SAP S/4HANA. The date to be shown in the report will correspond to the reservation of every material which appears in the configuration tool of the report. Target dates will only be available for columns where dates are coming from materials. In case dates coming from operations, target dates will be empty. Target dates will only be displayed on the Finish Date column, so that the Start Date column will be leave it empty.

Plan Dates will be the dates defined in SAP S/4HANA because of the planning (MRP Live), that is, the planned dates for a planning element of a given material, plant and WBS element (model-unit). The plant will be a selection screen field of the report. The planned dates will be first determined based on the open planned receipts on the stock/requirements list (module function BAPI_MATERIAL_STOCK_REQ_LIST). If no elements selected in the previous step, then closed planned receipts (finally delivered) will be considered, based on the good movements already completed. The date will be the planned date of the element for which the good receipt has been completed (last good movement executed or with the most recent date). In case dates coming from operations, plan dates will come from corresponding operation planned dates.

Actual Dates will be the real dates of the order execution. The actual dates will be first determined based on the planning elements with material movements (good receipts) for a given material, plant and WBS element (model-unit). If not, based on the posting date (MATDOC-BUDAT) of the good movements already completed (last good movement executed or with the most recent date). In case dates coming from operations, actual dates will come from the real confirmation posting dates of the corresponding operations (first confirmation for Start Date and last confirmation for Finish Date).

 

Realization of the Manufacturing Dates Report

The dynamic configuration of the report layout was achieved by using maintenance cluster technology on three levels. Thereby a configuration cluster (transaction SE54) was created with several configuration tables and three hierarchy levels, as already explained in previous design point (layouts level, columns level, columns criteria level). As the identification of the configuration level for a model is done by the assignation of a specific model type (for example, aircraft final assembly, left wing, center fuselage, wheelset), layouts were uniquely assigned to a specific model type.

Image 7. Example of layout level for the configuration tool.

Image 8. Example of columns level for the configuration tool.

Image 9. Example of columns criteria level for the configuration tool.

The selection screen of the manufacturing dates report was the following:

Image 10. Selection screen of the manufacturing dates report.

By selecting a Model Type, the selection of the Layout ID was restricted (view help) to those assigned to this specific model type. The Plant was also required for fetching the planning elements data at plant level. Either a Project or a WBS Element was also necessary to limit the data to specific project objects. The different Date Types could be displayed or hidden by using the corresponding checkboxes (at least one is required). A Date Range was also mandatory to limit the data fetching of the planning elements to specific time horizon.

An example of the output list for the manufacturing dates report with the previous example of configuration layout is the following:

Image 11. Example of output list for the manufacturing dates report.

Columns with date type “Material” correspond with dates on planning elements for the material/s belonging to the related column criteria.

Image 12. Planning elements for columns with date type “Material”.

Columns with date type “Operation” match with the related operation numbers of the routing (shop floor routing on PEO):

Image 13. Columns with date type “Operation” and related operation numbers of the routing.

Below you can display an example of how dates are calculated for one model-unit of a project, when planning elements are planned orders, for the different date types (rows) and the different process steps (columns):

Image 14. Example of calculated dates from planned orders on manufacturing dates report.

As only the internally produced materials were initially considered, plan dates can come from both planned orders and production orders, but actual dates only proceed from production orders. To know how firmed the dates are, the report differentiates dates coming from the different planning elements (and with different status) by using different cell colors, which are the following:

  • Planned Order (white color with text on blue color)
  • Production Order on status Created (blue color)
  • Production Order on status Released (green color)

Image 15. Example of output list with cell color coding for the manufacturing dates report.

Below you can display another example of how dates are calculated for one model-unit of a project, when planning elements are production orders, for the different date types (rows) and the different process steps (columns):

Image 16. Example of calculated dates from production orders on manufacturing dates report.

Finally, a customized data exportation process to Microsoft Excel was also implemented on button “Export Data to Excel”, to obtain the specific layout requested by the customer.

Image 17. Manufacturing dates report exported to Microsoft Excel.

 

Improvements of the Manufacturing Dates Report

Several improvements were requested after the first version of the manufacturing dates report, as users became aware of missing scenarios or new needs arising from the daily use of the report. The following is a not exhaustive list of these improvements:

1. External Procurement Scenario

Besides planned orders and production orders for the internally produced materials, more planning elements were considered for the report. Planned elements for the externally procured materials were also considered, specifically purchase requisitions and purchase orders (also shipping notifications). Dates coming from these new planning elements were identified by using cell color yellow.

Image 18. Example of output list with cell color coding for the manufacturing dates report.

2. Cross-Plant Scenario

The report was initially considering manufacturing only in one single plant. Thus cross-plant scenario where demand on one plant but manufacturing happens on another plant was missing. Customer requested to also cover this scenario with some assumptions:

  • The production on the other plant will be under the same WBS element, that is, same project, model and unit.
  • There will be only one step per plant.
  • The manufacturing will be at plant level, not at MRP area (storage location) level.

3. Groping WBS Scenario

Users realized that there was a small group of unitized materials displayed on the report for which the dates were empty, and reason was that they were being managed by grouping (PMMO). Customer requested to also cover this scenario, so report was adapted to fetch data at model/unit level for these materials, instead of WBS level.

Image 19. Operative WBS elements vs. Grouping WBS elements

4. Assembly Sequence

For some business units it was possible to stablish an assembly sequence and a relation between the different elements of the main units containing several model/units. This was managed on a configuration table called configuration level relationship. Customer requested to include this info on the manufacturing dates report. Therefore, it was possible to order lines by sequence, thus displaying the assembly sequence with corresponding target/plan/real dates aside.

Image 20. Planned assembly sequence on configuration level relationship table.

Image 21. Example of output list with assembly sequence for the manufacturing dates report.

5. Materials Managed in PP/DS

PP/DS was active for some plants and for some material types and/or groups. Customer requested to get more accurate production dates from PP/DS layer instead of S/4 layer, for those internally procured materials managed in PP/DS, and report was changed accordingly.

 

Variant of the Report for Misalignment between Dates

Users noticed that they did not have a proactive way to check for projects with incorrect dates. They were able to display these misalignments on the report, but this was done going project by project and reviewing the dates one by one.

Customer requested a similar report to easily find misalignments between the planned dates entered by Planning (“Target Date”) and the planned dates calculated by MRP Live (“End Plan Date”) and/or later changed by planners. For this new report, the plant and the material were also required in the output list. This was achieved with a fixed layout by merging the information coming from rows "Target Date" and "Plan Date" in the same line, and then including a new column called “Days” after the date columns. “Days” column displayed the difference in days between the End Plan Date and Target Date, corresponding to the same model and unit.

A new checkbox “Display only date differences” was also included on the selection screen, to display only lines where difference exists between target and plan dates, to exclusively focus on misalignments.

Image 22. Example of output list for the manufacturing dates misalignment report.

 

Helpful Links

Product Unitization based on Parameter Effectivity (SAP Help Portal)

Complex Assembly Manufacturing (SAP Help Portal)

 

[Disclaimer: Written by Juan Ventura (LinkedIn). This blog post is written by the author based on his personal experience while working on customers with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. Opinions and views expressed herein are solely my own. Before implementing any solution, you are advised to always do the analysis and adopt a solution for specific business case only if it suits customer requirements and testing is successful.]

entry.title: Choosing the right path to Cloud ERP
entry.content:
For many SAP-using organizations, moving to Cloud ERP is not a question of if but how. And businesses are feeling the pressure. End-of-support for ECC is fast approaching and many of SAP’s newest innovations are offered only in the Cloud.

Despite the urgency, more than half of SAP users have yet to begin their migration. One of the biggest hurdles is choosing the right path to Cloud ERP.

At first, this might seem like a simple decision between Public Cloud ERP and Private Cloud ERP. Yet, the choice is far more complex. It requires careful consideration of your business priorities, regulatory requirements, and landscape complexity.

Public vs Private

It’s tempting to view Public Cloud ERP as a one-size-fits-all solution, with limited flexibility. Public Cloud ERP is often described as a standardized, SAP-managed solution with a Clean Core – where most customizations move to external platforms like BTP. Private Cloud ERP is seen as the more flexible alternative, particularly for organizations needing to retain legacy customizations.

While there is some truth to that distinction, it oversimplifies the reality for businesses considering shifting to the Cloud. The real difference is less about whether you can customize, but where and how.

In Public Cloud, extensions and customizations, mostly occur outside the core ERP system. Unlike Public Cloud, Private Cloud permits more change to the core ERP system and offers more options that address end-user requirements such as hosting preferences and underlying technology.

The Many Variations of Private Cloud

For larger enterprises, Private Cloud is the likely choice. Yet, that choice is anything but straightforward. Over time, SAP has expanded beyond a single core offering of Private Cloud ERP (formerly RISE), offering numerous options designed to meet distinct needs, whether infrastructure preferences, regulatory compliance, or phased migration timelines.

 

Some examples of Private Cloud include:

  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition: Classic RISE with SAP option and the right choice for many enterprises
  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition Tailored: Contracted options are customized per unique customer requirements. May include contracted coverage for many responsibilities considered customer concerns in the base offering.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Sovereign Cloud: Keeps all data and processing within a particular jurisdiction or geography. It’s ideal when technical or regulatory requirements make traditional off-site hosting infeasible.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Hyperscaler: Runs on the customer’s preferred hyperscaler, often leveraging an existing relationship.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Hyperscaler Tailored: Modified version of Cloud ERP running on the customer’s existing hyperscaler environment. Offers additional flexibility for deployment architecture and may be more suitable for migrating highly integrated or complex existing on-premises implementations.
  • SAP ERP Customer Datacenter Edition: Brings Cloud architecture into a company’s datacentre when external hosting isn’t feasible.
  • SAP Cloud ERP Private Edition Transition Option: A commercial offering enabling enterprises to commit to Cloud ERP while keeping ECC supported past 2027 and through 2033.

The number of Cloud ERP options can be overwhelming. Yet, it also means you can choose an offering closely aligned with your strategic goals.

Key considerations for your Cloud journey

There are more options available than many SAP-using organizations realize. The best outcomes come from asking the right questions and focusing on what matters most to your business.

  • Customization: Do we have significant existing customizations? How critical are these customizations? Is code going to be retained or modernized? Where does redevelopment or customization take place?
  • Compliance: What compliance or jurisdictional requirements govern where data can reside?
  • Cloud partnership: How important is leveraging an existing hyperscaler contract or infrastructure investment?
  • Timeline: Do we anticipate maintaining ECC beyond standard support timelines, and if so, what transition paths exist?

Look beyond Public and Private and focus on business realities. In this way, you can identify an option that balances flexibility, control, and long-term viability. It means businesses can avoid putting operations and compliance at risk as they migrate to the Cloud.

The Bottom Line

The journey to Cloud ERP is rarely straightforward. No two organizations have the same requirements and goals. What’s clear is that there is no universal answer. Public Cloud offers speed, standardization, lower total cost of ownership, automatic SAP updates, and scalability. Private Cloud provides flexibility, with choices built to address distinct business challenges.

The right choice depends on aligning your migration strategy with business outcomes. Focus on your requirements and chart a course that ensures your ERP landscape remains a foundation for growth, innovation, and resilience today and in the future.

entry.title: SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf featured two hands-on sessions plus AI everywhere
entry.content:
SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf continued the momentum of the UX Foundation team showing the latest embedded AI features in My Home and the SAP Fiori elements framework. At our event on December 9, 2025, customers spent a day learning, developing, and networking with each other, SAP experts, and the sponsors.

Hands-on sessions showed how AI speeds application development

New for this iteration of SAP Fiori Innovation Day, we added an additional hands-on session beyond our usual one where people develop an SAP Fiori elements app using building blocks. The new one allowed people to try agentic app development with common AI clients and SAP’s MCP servers. This is a great way to save time creating SAP Fiori apps and an approach we are starting to use at SAP.

We also discussed the quality of AI-created code. Even if AI generates something faster than you could on your own, it is mandatory for you to understand the code so you can check it in with confidence and explain (or defend) anything during a code review. One of our architects explained that “I don’t know; the AI wrote this part” is not an acceptable answer. His main message was: “as a developer, you own the code.”

Graphic of the schedule for SAP Fiori Innovation Day in Walldorf

SAP Fiori continues to evolve to make SAP Cloud ERP easier to use

The day started with an overview of SAP Fiori and what this looks like in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. It included a discussion of the SAP Design System and how that includes common themes for UX consistency and enterprise product standards such as accessibility to help both designers and developers create applications that end users love.

Graphic showing overall strategy for SAP’s products

Demos illustrated and reinforced the points made in the slides. Similar to how you would begin your day with SAP Cloud ERP, we started with My Home and all the different ways you have to launch apps and make the page your own. The intro session also covered adjacent UX topics such as SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Start, and SAP’s mobile apps as well as a discussion of Joule and how it adds value across SAP’s portfolio.

Graphic showing Joule interaction patterns.

SAP Fiori includes more AI capabilities for business users

The afternoon demos were split into generally available and beta functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The released functionality included:

My Home

  • Card creation in My Home– creates cards that display essential business data that you can add to My Home
  • Joule-assisted insight card creation in My Home– ask Joule for the information you need and create a card that you can add to My Home
  • Recap – shows changes to tasks, cards, and app since you last accessed the system, making it easy to see what you missed when you were away

The recap feature in My Home shows you what changed in the system since your last access.

SAP Fiori elements apps

  • Easy filter – natural language searching in SAP Fiori elements list reports
  • Smart summarization – AI-created summary of SAP Fiori elements object pages
  • Error explanation – AI-assisted content that explains the meaning of error and provides suggestions on how to clear the error condition

Later in our “the future (one more thing)” session, we shared with some previews of planned AI functionality that will first be released into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Editon.

  • Easy Fill – copies text from an email or other source into the relevant fields on an object page
  • AI-assisted task automation (development code name “Smart Helpers”) – allows business users to automate steps in one or more SAP Fiori apps to streamline a complex process

Easy fill is currently in beta testing with selected public cloud customers. AI-assisted task automation is still in development.

The partners shared different ways to build the future you want in your SAP environment

The gold sponsors for SAP Fiori Innovation Day, eXXcellent solutions, cbs, and sovanta,  presented on topics that engaged the audience as each focused on solving a specific problem common to SAP ERP customers.

  • eXXcellent talked about how to add AI capabilities to your SAP system, even if you are running SAP S/4HANA on-prem.
  • cbs covered how to decrypt SAP error messages with AI, BTP, and a little magic from a tool they have created called ADAM.
  • sovanta discussed how to prioritize what apps to develop, since the cost of building apps is dropping significantly due to AI.

Thanks to everyone who made SAP Fiori Innovation Day a success

  • SAP Presenters (in order of appearance): Thomas Reiss, Katrin Polloczek, Ioannis Grammatikakis, Yeganeh Hajimiri, Katya Bondarenko, Marcel Kassner, Christoph Gollmick.
  • Gold sponsors eXXcellent solutions, cbs, and sovanta
  • Silver sponsors: Uniorg and STELACON
  • Behind the scenes team: all the developers, architects, product managers and other colleagues who built the features we showed, tested the systems, wrote the documentation, packaged the demos, and created the hands-on exercises.
  • Our executive sponsors: Alex Lingg, Ioannis Grammatikakis, Sebastian Steinhauer, Katja Zoch
  • Special thanks to Sebastian Werner and Conny Kinateder for all the logistics work that made everything run smoothly for the customers and partners.

Thanks to all the participants for their enthusiasm and great, probing questions throughout the event. Your feedback on what we showed helps us prioritize our development going forward. The conversations in the hallway, at the coffee machine, and during meals give us a deeper sense of where you are in your SAP Fiori adoption and how we can best serve your interests.

Next steps

  • Register for the monthly SAP Fiori development roundtable call to meet other developers and architects who build SAP Fiori apps.
  • Subscribe to the SAP Fiori development newsletter, in which we share updates on SAP Fiori elements, SAP Fiori tools, SAPUI5, and SAP Build Code every other month.  
  • Join us at an SAP Fiori Development Innovation Day in 2026 – we are looking at locations, dates, and some new event formats.

On behalf of the SAP UX Foundation Team, Peter Spielvogel.

entry.title: ABAP Platform in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA 2025 were released to the SAP customer base on October 8, 2025.

ABAP Platform 2025 is the technology platform underlying the release 2025 of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA and is shipped as part of these products, supporting only SAP HANA database with full exploitation of its advanced capabilities. In addition,  ABAP Platform 2025 is part of SAP S/4HANA Foundation 2025 for SAP HANA-only Add-Ons.

ABAP Platform 2025 is not shipped as a standalone product. ABAP Platform 2025 consists of the AS ABAP,  the ABAP development tools for Eclipse, and several additional technology components which are required to run SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA.

Previous versions of SAP S/4HANA Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA such as 1610, 1709, 1809, 1909, 2020, 2021, 2022 and 2023 can be upgraded directly to the 2025 release, which is based on ABAP Platform 2025 (corresponding to SAP_BASIS 816).

Product Highlights

Presentation

This presentation provides the SAP official external slide deck, just click on it to view:

Overview

ABAP Platform 2025 delivers innovations for the ABAP stack in different areas.

Clean core development

In August 2025, SAP enhanced its extensibility guidelines by introducing the new Clean core extensibility white paper. The sustainable and upgrade-safe ABAP extensibility model in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA fully relies on SAP clean core guiding principles, aiming to decouple custom extensions from SAP standard whenever possible. The refined SAP guidance for extensibility replaces binary clean core decisions with a more nuanced evaluation of classic ABAP extensions based on the clean core level concept. Evolving from the previous 3-tier model, the new extensibility model categorizes extensions into four levels (A, B, C, and D) and provides rules for ABAP classic extensions to meet the clean core level qualifications. Following this new clean core extensibility guidance the ABAP extensibility guide was updated with technical guidelines to support the clean core level concept. The ABAP extensibility model was changed from 3-tier model to ABAP Cloud development (level A) and classic ABAP development (levels B, C and D).

The overall clean core guidance remained unchanged: always striving for the highest possible level of extensibility. ABAP Cloud is the SAP’s recommended development model for all new custom extensions in SAP S/4HANA private cloud and on-premise systems, whereby the classic ABAP extensibility can still be used to reach clean core, with a focus on upgrade-stability and code quality. This enables SAP customers and partners to transition to a clean core incrementally and at their own speed. SAP provides guidance for ABAP clean core development by offering a recommended list of APIs (so-called “classic APIs”) to be used in classic ABAP development. For governance of ABAP clean core development, the ABAP test cockpit (ATC) now supports the clean core level concept with new ATC checks (see the blog post ABAP test cockpit (ATC) recommendations for governance of clean core ABAP development). For governance of ABAP development for clean core in SAP S/4HANA private cloud or on-premise systems the remote ATC in SAP BTP ABAP environment is the SAP recommended approach. 

SAP Joule for Developers,  ABAP AI capabilities

SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI capabilities are now key components and an integral part of AI-assisted ABAP Cloud development, also facilitating custom code transformation from ECC to SAP S/4HANA. The capabilities supporting developer tasks include Joule copilot in ABAP development tools for Eclipse, predictive code completion, code explanation and unit test generation for ABAP and ABAP CDS, app and service generation (including RAP BO generation), predictive business logic for RAP BOs, and OData consumption. The provided ABAP AI SDK, powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM), can be utilized for the implementation of AI capabilities in custom applications.

The custom code migration capabilities include docs chat for questions around custom code migration and S/4HANA simplifications, explanation of business purpose and processing logic of legacy code (ABAP reports), explanation of S/4HANA-related ATC findings in custom code, along with resolution recommendations based on S/4HANA simplification items and cookbooks (see the blog post SAP Joule for Developers Expands to Private Cloud: Accelerating ABAP Innovation and Transformation).

ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model (RAP)

Another major investment area in the 2025 release is the ABAP RESTful Application Programming Model, which powers modern development in both ABAP Cloud and classic ABAP, enabling the creation of delightful transactional SAP Fiori apps as well as local and web APIs. This release delivers new features to accelerate and enhance the development with RAP, including new generators to boost efficiency, support of CDS table entities as persistence layer, various capabilities for SAP Fiori elements-based UIs, such as collaborative draft, cross-BO scenarios, tree views, and event-driven side effects, as well as end-to-end extensibility options.

New ABAP Cloud generators for creating OData UI services with RAP BOs (with one or more entities) from scratch, with or without AI assistance, or for generating custom UI service based on RAP BO interface are provided. ABAP CDS table entities can be used as active persistence layer for managed RAP BOs without draft, replacing classic dictionary database tables.

Enhancements for building of SAP Fiori elements-based apps with RAP include the collaborative draft handling, which allows multiple users to work simultaneously and collaboratively on the same draft instance of an entity without blocking one another. You can now also build SAP Fiori UIs that use multiple RAP BOs interacting with each other. These cross-BO scenarios rely on cross-BO transactional enablement, where the entities of the participating RAP BOs are linked through so-called cross-BO associations. Read-only and editable tree view supports displaying and manipulating hierarchical data in SAP Fiori UIs, with options for drag and drop, cut and paste, reordering, and cascading delete. Event-driven RAP side effects enable asynchronous updates in SAP Fiori UIs. When such a specific RAP business event is raised, the associated side effect is triggered, and the defined targets are reloaded in the UI.

The privileged context can now be propagated in subsequent Entity Manipulation Language (EML) requests in reading and modifying operation. Further enhancement for the behavior definitions and the behavior pools are provided with this release.

ABAP development tools for Eclipse (ADT)

Various enhancements are provided in ABAP development tools for Eclipse for ABAP development, RAP and ABAP CDS related development aspects, testing and troubleshooting, as well as overall IDE and productivity improvements.

Refactoring support for ABAP classes and interfaces was improved by activation of renaming changes by default, validation of new names and displaying long texts of exceptions. The new where-used dialog enables prefiltering of search results to focus on usages relevant for the concrete use case. There is a new property abaplv to filter object searches with the ABAP language version. There are new editors like for example for working with software component relations, Adobe Forms or maintaining intelligent scenarios and intelligent scenarios models which are required to run a solution based on generative AI. It is possible to create and edit CDS table entities and create for them behavior definitions.

In the area of ABAP unit tests, method calls in test classes can now be highlighted in different colors to distinguish their method contexts. Quick actions allow tests to be launched or templates for test classes to be inserted with a single mouse click. The failed assertions and status of test methods can be displayed directly in the source code editor. The unit tests can be rerun with coverage and coverage results can be cleared in the ABAP Coverage view. Additionally, there is a new AMDP Test Double Framework, and the CDS Test Double Framework now supports CDS hierarchy views.

In the ABAP debugger, it is now possible to display the memory consumption of a debugged ABAP program in the new ABAP Memory (Debugger) view. The ABAP Memory Snapshot view lists all memory snapshots, which can be opened in the editor to show memory objects ranked by size. These views make it easier to analyze the memory usage of an ABAP application. Internal tables can now be easily compared using the table comparison tool within the ABAP debugger. Beyond this, the ABAP debugger can now consider variables with hidden values (for sensitive data), display variables of type JSON, and show component groups for nested structures in the Variables view. Collaborative error analysis is supported by export/import of ABAP Cross Trace results to/from JSON file or export of short dumps as ZIP file in the ABAP Runtime Error Viewer.

Beyond this there are also enhancements in transport management for adding an object to a transport or searching and grouping transport requests.

ABAP Language

The modern, declarative, and expression-oriented ABAP language allows writing simple and concise ABAP code through features such as inline declarations and constructor expressions. Advanced operations for internal tables include grouping, filtering, and the CORRESPONDING( ) operator. The cloud-optimized version “ABAP for Cloud Development” is used for ABAP Cloud development.

There are further enhancements for internal tables, including support for arbitrary logical expressions and equality conditions, as well as harmonization of table expressions and READ TABLE statement. New ABAP system classes for probability distributions are provided, enabling the generation of random number and the calculation of quantile, probabilities, and other aspects. These classes support various discrete and continuous distributions. This release also delivers enhancements for expressions and functions, as well as for transformations, such as the new domain XSDGEO for serializing and deserializing spatial data between the Extended Well-Known Binary (EWKB) representation and the GeoJSON format.

SAP HANA-centric optimizations & Data Integration scenarios

Modern ABAP development on SAP HANA has been enhanced with several advanced, database-centric features also enriching data integration scenarios. Recent innovations in data integration focus on data exposure, including ABAP-managed database procedures for advanced read scenarios.  With CDS updatable view entities it is now possible to wrap existing DDIC database tables (or CDS table entities) and expose a native CDS signature, which can be used with ABAP SQL in combination with DCL-based access control. 

On the consumption side, new write scenarios, the use of static CDS external entities, and the possibility to create ABAP CDS models based on imported CDS models make it easier than ever to integrate external data seamlessly into an ABAP CDS view stack.

Additional enhancements, such as CDS table entities to define and manage SAP HANA database tables as native CDS repository objects, a CDS generation wizard to simplify and automate the creation of hierarchically structured data in ABAP CDS, and AI-powered CDS Explain to get semantical context information about CDS entities further brighten the ABAP development landscape.

Embedded analytics

For embedded analytics scenarios it is now possible to expedite development workflow using ABAP Cloud generator wizards for creation of multidimensional analysis apps, Review Booklet apps, or native CDS hierarchy definitions. With the introduction of reusable measures and filters, the key figures, measures, filters and many more features can now be defined centrally, based on user needs to better manage and align analytical reporting. They can also be utilized in CDS view entities to ensure homogenous definition of complex calculations and unification of coherences of the running business.

Event Enablement & Business Events

The event-driven architecture of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA is strengthened, and the interoperability across enterprise solutions is improved through seamless integration with SAP Event Mesh Advanced Plan and support of SAP Cloud Application Event Hub to consume events published by SAP Order Management Foundation on SAP BTP.

The event-driven processing and monitoring was enhanced with new outbound event filtering, enabling selective publishing based on configurable criteria, and dynamic topics in SAP Event Mesh Advanced Plan for more efficient routing. Operational transparency was improved through comprehensive event logging, including local capture and logging of successfully processed events. Events of the same type and object within a session can now be grouped as activities, improving traceability and reducing monitoring noise. Together, these features provide a scalable and well-governed foundation for event-driven architecture.

Process integration & Connectivity

Key highlights of process integration include a robust OData service consumption model with Swagger UI preview and advanced OData V4 capabilities, such as bulk processing and asynchronous communication integrated with AIF. The API governance and communication management was enhanced by introducing Communication Targets within Communication Arrangements, enabling more granular control over connectivity endpoints. API lifecycle management is improved through API-to-package assignment and the ability to create API packages for better organization across API types. Additionally, OData-based access to Communication Management data increases automation, transparency, and integration with external tools.

Additional connectivity improvements include outbound communication enablement via HTTP and RFC, support for setting the AIR key as a custom HTTP header in SOAP requests for more secure message handling, direct push-based data exchange between ABAP systems via RFC, and SSE support in the ABAP HTTP client and server for efficient real-time event delivery in distributed scenarios.

Key user extensibility

Further improvements are provided for key user extensibility. It is now possible to generate a Fiori elements application for a custom business object with just one click and maintain behavior extensions for SAP-provided RAP business objects using key user extensibility. Moreover, using developer extensibility it is now possible to implement feature control for custom fields that were created via the Custom Fields app. The new extension field wizard provides a better development efficiency by boosting the creation of custom fields via developer extensibility.

Security

Key updates include support for OAuth Authorization Code with PKCE (RFC 7636) and JWT-based client authentication (RFC 7523), as well as SAP-managed client certificates for secure integration in S/4HANA Private Cloud (2025 FPS01). TLS 1.3 is now supported across HTTP, WebSocket RFC, and SMTP, with OAuth Client Credential Grant enabled for SMTP outbound scenarios such as Exchange Online.

Additional enhancements include new OpenID Connect features, improved troubleshooting guidance (SAP Note 3111813), and a new OAuth Client Configuration UI (SOAUTH_CLIENT) with built-in testing and token metadata display. 

Useful Blog Posts, Community pages and Learnings
